Going to start by saying you don't need to know a thing about Spider-Man to enjoy this. My previous knowledge was memes and hearing friends talk about it. I still loved this.

It's been a long time since I had this much fun in a game! I pretty much no lifed this since I couldn't put it down. 

The story is really good and easy to follow, even for those not versed in the Marvel universe (like me) There might be some references that could be missed but it really doesn't take too much away from the story when you don't know what you're missing. There's some really likable and well written characters and the dialogue is pretty solid. They also hired some great voice actors for this that make the characters feel more like real people.

The parkour in this is probably my favourite of any game that I've played. Quite a few of my hours are just me web slinging around and enjoying the view (Speaking of view, it also has a great photo mode to catch some cool screenshots) It feels really responsive for the most part, though it can be annoying trying to change direction on a wall if you're scaling it. The rest feels great though.

Combat is fantastic in my humble opinion. It's not a mash this button over and over but there's different moves to enjoy as you kick the bad guys asses. Lots of fun gadgets to enjoy and switch up the combat and make that combo rise. It can take a little bit of learning (not too much) but it feels so satisfying when it clicks and you're pretty much untouchable in some encounters with the combat flow.

As a 100% this was an absolute blast! There are collectibles but they're all listed on the map and with the web slinging, they're a lot of fun to get to. Nothing is missable and you can even continue after the final quest for clean up. Side quests are fun and I'd recommend doing them, even if you aren't a completionist.

DLC's were also quite fun to go through, though I did feel in it that I was missing some context from not knowing about the world. It's easy to fill in the gaps for the most part though.

I'm already excited to dive into the 2nd one.

Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered delivers a highly enjoyable open-world adventure that successfully captures the spirit of playing as Spider-Man. While it has its flaws, the overall package is worth recommending.

Exceptional Traversal: The web-swinging mechanics across Manhattan are fantastic. They are fluid, engaging, and make moving around the city the game's best feature. It's the primary reason to keep playing.

Accessible Combat: The fighting is generally fun, visually appealing, and satisfyingly fast-paced. It's easy to pick up, leaning into a style that's quite forgiving. This often puts it in the "easy win" category, as it doesn't provide a significant challenge. The combat only gets genuinely difficult in situations where you are overwhelmed, such as being surrounded by 20 enemies who frequently attack from off-screen or outside the hero's view.

Weak Narrative: The plot is arguably the weakest part. It's formulaic, pretentious, and overall just mediocreâ€”classic superhero boilerplate with little originality.

Good Pacing (Despite the Story): A saving grace is that the cutscenes are kept reasonably brief, ensuring you can quickly return to the gameplay loop.

Ubisoft-Style Map Bloat: The game eventually starts adding a plethora of (repetitive) objective markers to the city map, such as "climb tower to unlock map segment" or "complete X challenge as fast as possible." When this starts, you might think, "Oh no, not again." However, due to how incredibly satisfying and fun the traversal is, even these checklist activities become surprisingly enjoyable and never truly feel like a chore. The sheer pleasure of swinging makes clearing the map a low-stress activity.

Steam Deck Performance:
A great experience for portable play. Using custom medium settings with FSR (no Frame Generation) allowed for a 45 FPS play, making it a highly playable title on the Steam Deck.

Final Verdict: Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered is a super fun, high-quality game that perfectly executes the fantasy of swinging through a major city. While the story is weak and the open-world design is conventional, the excellent traversal and fun combat make it a solid and easy recommendation. It's a great game, but perhaps not a masterpiece.

Marvel's Spider Man was a true near masterpiece of a video game capturing the pure essence of what it was like to be Peter Parker. Lets talk pros and cons:

Pros:

Graphics - The game is stunning. Swinging around NYC, the attention to detail is insane. All the way down to the local mom and pop pizza shop, you see everything in this game and they don't hold back. The ability effects, enemy attacks, even the vehicles and surrounding water, it all looks stunning.

Gameplay - This game features top tier gameplay, a nice well paced upgrade system that gives you just enough for it to feel different everytime as you continue to level and play the game. The amount of gadgets is insane and you can really customize how you go about each encounter. The dodge system with the combo system flows well, similiar to batman arkham series. Overall theres so much fun gameplay to be had here, with very minimal faults (but there are faults).

Story - The story is pretty good, i wouldnt call it a 10/10 knock out, but its definitely well above average, featuring some of spider mans most notorious villians and the pre nerf mary jane, it all comes together nicely as a good packaged spider man story that made you want to have more. The DLC is even good as well, with black cats DLC being the best imo. 

Difficulty - The game has a wide range of difficulties available. I 78/78 perfected this game so I beat it on ultimate and it wasnt that much of a step up in difficulty. I feel like alot of it is stream lined until you are on either end of the extremes. 

Suits / Gear - There is SO many suits. A fuck ton of suits. Unlocking the suits and gadgets are fun and will definitely keep you wanting to do the mediocre grind stuff just to unlock more suits. 

Cons:

Mediocre Grind - The game has alot of grind to it. They love adding their open world nonsense to do in the game to keep you busy and to make you think its a longer game than it actually is. Theres like 15 different things to do at any given moment and most of which is basic find this, kill that, stop this kind of system. 

Boring Mary Jane And Miles Missions - I absolutely hated the mary jane and miles missions. They completely killed the flow of the game when they showed on screen and while I get it from a story perspective I feel like there was just quite frankly too much. People want to play as spider man, not mary jane or miles without his powers. Super slow forced BS to keep the momentum down and extend the game.

Repetitive - The game can start feeling repetitive really fast with all the same mission types to do over and over and over again to unlock gadgets and suits. 

Overall Marvel Spider-man is a ton of fun and will absolutely make you feel like you are Peter Parker himself. Its a great game thats bogged down by boring side character missions and repetitive mission design but when its on beat, its incredible. 

Thanks for reading.

Seeing how this is: 
- the 2nd highest selling PS4 game of all time: 
  -- especially how late during the console's life-cycle it was released
- Spider-Man 2 is the highest selling PS5 game of all time
I thought I would have nothing to lose getting it. I bought it via a CD key and took the risk; which excludes it from Steam's refund policy. 

But this goes to show, that, both mass critic and user reviews, cannot be relied upon as it is mostly generated hype and cult followings, favouring style over substance.

This game unfortunately falls into the generic Ubisoft sandbox. The map is huge, but there is little ways to interact with the world. The people walking around are nothing but cardboard NPCs, and the buildings are just blocks for you to swing off. There are no interiors and few unique charms that make exploring the city worth while. A denser, more alive open world with more content would have done this world favours.

The physics and controls are pretty tight. Spiderman has a varied move-set and the combat is somewhat similar to Batman Arkham series, where you have to perform timed dodges, deal with enemies wielding melee or ranged weapons, shields etc which means you have to spin a different combo to deal with them and not mash the same buttons. That part works, what doesn't is the overall game-loop. 

- the graphics are not that great, older titles like MGS Phantom Pain look far more stunning
- there is no day and night cycle or changes to weather - they do change based on story script only, so if you are just exploring, the world feels static, not dynamic.
- the side-quests are just generic activities:
  -- wave fights: (personally I think this is one of the lowest forms of gameplay, to program it you just need a simple loop of enemy respawns and triggered conditions). The particular waves in this game get very tiresome, it isn't a matter of skill, but endurance.
-- crimes: a bit better than endless waves, short and sweet, but nothing special. Vehicle chases means swinging after a vehicle, then pressing some Quick Time Events to watch a few animations.
  -- collectibles: backpacks, pidgeons etc. simply means gathering them. There isn't a skill based challenge or a gadget themed puzzle requiring you to get them. Reaching the pointer on the map and grabbing them is enough
  -- Ubisoft towers (really dated legacy mechanic most people are tired off, interact with a tower, reveal portion of the map)
  -- photographs landmarks (there are a few unique buildings, you just pull out the camera and snap a photo)
- full of mundane progression minigames - if anyone remembers Bioshock's Pipe-Dream hacking minigame, well this is back, but in the form of electric circuits. I never liked minigames, I just want to play the game, but when you have to repeat the same minigame over and over it gets stale and repetitive very quickly. In contrast to Arkham, those games require you use your gadgets to interact with your environment, where as here you find detached minigames that don't at all link to Spiderman or any of his tools. 
  -- Luckily, accessibility options do allow you to skip them entirely, which I did gladly.
- Skill trees: in the 2010s era every exclusive sandbox had to have the 3 skill trees: tap A to do this faster; take less damage;  something affects 1 more enemy etc. - quantitative checkbox updates rather than quality updates that affect how you interact with the world.
- enemy AI is not dynamic and reactive like in Arkham, they won't start destroying perch points once they see you them. They will behave in the same manner throughout
- The MJ and Miles sections are scripted, linear stealth sections. You cannot change how its done or pick your own route, you go from point to point as you're told and cannot deviate from this line.
- I don't know why so many devs obsessed with cinema do this, but if you want to explain a narrative, just add a cutscene. Instead you will be stopped with many sections that require forced walking, you walk around a room, and press the action button to interact with an object, the character speaks some monologue about what you saw, then you have to repeat this several times until you have interacted with enough objects/the correct object. Again, I just want to play the real game, save these interaction sequences for cutscenes, don't force me to hold "up" for 5 minutes pressing "Y" to move the game forward.

The pluses are:
+ lots of different suits, gadgets and suit mods to modify your play style
+ controls and physics feel tight
+ web slinging feels tight and controlled
+ map is large
+ lots of Marvel characters make an appearance

Overall I really find it hard to understand how this outsold, especially so much later in the console's lifecycle, much more dynamic and innovative titles like Red Dead Redemption 2, Witcher 3 and MGS Phantom Pain. The game mostly borrows all of its mechanics from other titles, but doesn't contribute anything innovative of its own.

My recommendation is to buy this from Steam directly, that way if you don't like it and played under 2 hours, you can refund it - this will give you ample time to test it, as what you see in those 2 hours is what you will get throughout. Or try to see if you can play a demo version. 

If you find yourself that you are not tired of generic open world games like Assassin's Creed and many other Ubisoft titles, then you can probably sink into this. But if you strive for quality and innovation, try the demo before buying (or buy directly from Steam, and request a refund in under 2 hours). To me a lot of this is very last gen, if it came out in 2012 it would have been top tier, but even Arkham City outclasses this game and has a more unique variety of activities in its sandbox, despite having a much smaller world. And that being said, I also think that most Ubisoft sandboxes are actually a lot more fun than this game, even AC Odyssey whose map is far too large and has literal fetch quests offers more thrills.
